name: Phantom Strike – APT29 Intrusion Simulation
description: Simulating a sophisticated spear-phishing and credential harvesting campaign by a foreign adversary targeting a U.S. defense contractor.

steps.title: Suspicious Email Received
steps.description: An employee receives an email from what appears to be a DoD subcontractor requesting invoice validation. The email contains a link to a OneDrive document.
options: Click the link to verify the invoice
Report the email to the SOC for analysis
Ignore the email

steps.title: SOC Email Triage
steps.description: You’re a SOC Tier 1 analyst reviewing the phishing alert. The email passed SPF but failed DKIM and DMARC. What’s your next step?
options: Escalate to Tier 2 with IOC enrichment request
Delete the email and notify IT
Mark the alert as benign

steps.title: Alert Correlation
steps.description: You pivot to log data and discover multiple users received similar emails within a 2-minute span. One user clicked the link. What should you do?
options: Escalate to IR and begin account review of the affected user
Delete all affected emails from inboxes
Send out a phishing awareness reminder

steps.title: IOC Validation
steps.description: You extract the domain from the email link and check against internal and external threat intelligence. It’s a known malicious C2 from APT29 activity.
options: Add domain to blocklist and send alert to IR
Flag it for later review
Create a custom rule to ignore this domain

steps.title: Credential Compromise Detected
steps.description: Network logs show an anomalous login from a Russian IP to the compromised user’s O365 account within an hour of the phishing email.
options: Reset user password and enable MFA
Ignore; the IP could be a false positive
Suspend the user's account and monitor logs

steps.title: Lateral Movement
steps.description: The adversary attempts to move laterally by accessing shared drives containing procurement data. EDR alerts are triggered.
options: Contain the host and pull forensic images
Delete the suspicious files
Send a company-wide alert

steps.title: Persistence Mechanism
steps.description: You discover a scheduled task and PowerShell backdoor set up to re-establish access after reboots.
options: Delete the task and restart the system
Reimage the host and update IOC signatures across the fleet
Block PowerShell execution across the org

steps.title: C2 Infrastructure Analysis
steps.description: The malware beacon connects to a domain registered through a known bulletproof hosting provider used by APT29.
options: Contact the registrar to take down the domain
Add the domain to the blocklist and share IOCs with CISA
Ignore and focus on internal containment

steps.title: Attribution Assessment
steps.description: Indicators of compromise match known APT29 infrastructure, including DNS patterns and malware signatures found in CISA advisories.
options: Attribute the attack to a generic actor
Attribute the attack to APT29 and notify federal authorities
Suppress the attribution until a breach disclosure is required

steps.title: Reporting & Disclosure
steps.description: Federal regulations require reporting certain breaches involving controlled unclassified information (CUI).
options: Wait until the investigation is fully complete
Notify the DoD and submit a report to CISA within 72 hours
Only notify after internal legal review approves

steps.title: Post-Incident Response
steps.description: The threat has been neutralized and logs analyzed. What is the best next step?
options: Conduct a tabletop exercise and implement phishing simulation training
Reassign all users to new teams
Disable remote access until further notice

steps.title: Long-Term Defense Strategy
steps.description: You want to improve resilience against similar APT tactics in the future.
options: Implement MFA and disable legacy authentication across the org
Increase antivirus scan frequency
Ban email attachments
